channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: A New Wave of Popular Fury Could Hit Europe in 2017
item.media:description: Supporters of “Brexit,” the British vote to leave the European Union, in London in June, before the referendum.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The past year has brought a series of political shocks to the continent, but 2017 promises to be even bumpier.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Italy Enters a Transition Phase, Complex but Familiar, as Its Premier Quits
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi of Italy announced his resignation at a news conference on Monday in Rome.
item.description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi tendered his resignation on Monday after voters rejected his constitutional overhaul plan.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Highlights: Italy Considers What’s Next After Matteo Renzi Loses Referendum
item.media:description: Italians against constitutional changes celebrated the results of the referendum on Sunday night in Rome.
item.description: Italy’s president said Mr. Renzi should complete the 2017 budget before stepping down as promised.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Manuel Valls Resigns as French Premier and Declares Presidential Bid
item.media:description: Prime Minister Manuel Valls in Évry, France, on Monday as he announced his intention to run for president.
item.description: The Socialist prime minister announced that he would run despite strong dissatisfaction with the current government and deep divisions on the left.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Shinzo Abe to Become First Japanese Leader to Visit Pearl Harbor
item.description: Mr. Abe’s trip this month to the site his country attacked 75 years ago will in effect be reciprocating a visit by President Obama to Hiroshima this year.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Confessions Obtained Under Duress Often Used in Chinese Courts, Report Says
item.media:description: Zhou Wangyan, a former land bureau official in Liling, China, in 2014. Mr. Zhou said that he was detained and tortured under the Communist Party’s secretive “shuanggui” program. A report released Tuesday by Human Rights Watch said that such claims were far from uncommon.
item.description: Evidence collected in secret Communist Party investigations, using threats and torture, is repurposed for criminal cases, Human Rights Watch said.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Death of Tamil Nadu’s Leader Leaves Power Vacuum in Southern India
item.media:description: Jayalalithaa Jayaram, chief minister of Tamil Nadu State, in May. Her autocratic style did not diminish her popularity, and may have enhanced it, especially among poor, lower-caste women.
item.description: Jayalalithaa Jayaram, 68, an imperious former starlet, died after a cardiac arrest and had groomed no successor.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Russia Says Talks With U.S. Will Discuss Deal for Aleppo Rebels
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings dominate an eastern Aleppo neighborhood as pro-government troops advanced toward the area on Monday.
item.description: The Russian foreign minister said that any insurgents who refused to leave under terms of an agreement would be considered terrorists and risked death.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Oil and Gas Industry Leaders Eagerly Take Stakes in Mexican Offshore Fields
item.media:description: A worker at a Petróleos Mexicanos refinery in Tula de Allende, Hidalgo, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Janet Jarman for The New York Times
item.description: Looking beyond current low oil prices, the companies paid billions in an auction of deepwater drilling rights in the Gulf of Mexico.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Supreme Court Justice Removes Brazil’s Senate Leader Amid Graft Case
item.media:description: Renan Calheiros attended a session at the Federal Senate in Basillia, Brazil, last week.
item.description: The ruling to remove Renan Calheiros comes as tensions have escalated between Congress and the judiciary over corruption investigations.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Global Health: Yellow Fever Epidemic in Africa Shows Gaps in Vaccine Pipeline
item.media:description: A child being vaccinated against yellow fever in the Democratic Republic of Congo in July.
item.description: The outbreak was stopped by a huge vaccination campaign that stretched supplies by diluting doses.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: What in the World: Caught With Your Pants Down? Must Be Christmas in Catalonia
item.media:description: “Caganer” figurines of Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and Donald J. Trump.
item.description: Irreverent “caganer” figurines, a Christmas tradition, depict celebrities and politicians in a rather rude position: squatting to defecate.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Currency Didn’t Really Drop, Despite Jitters Over Trump
item.media:description: A billboard displaying United States currency outside a bank in Beijing in November.
item.description: Some data services showed that the renminbi had been sharply devalued overnight, but a technical problem, not a decision by China, was responsible for the error.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: As Avianca Weighs Bids, Hedge Fund Plays Unusual Role: Diplomat
item.media:description: Germán Efromovich, right, the largest investor in Avianca Holdings, watched as the airline’s stock began trading on the New York Stock Exchange in 2013.
item.description: Delta, United and Copa have made offers to partner with the airline as Elliott Management mediates among shareholders.
item.dc:creator: LESLIE PICKER and ALEXANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: ‘Into Oblivion’ Uses Photography to Examine Lives of Dementia Patients
item.description: Maja Daniels spent almost a year talking to hospital staff and patients before starting her project about dementia.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS BAKALAR

item.title: Now That Italy Has Rejected Constitutional Amendments, What’s Next?
item.media:description: Posters in Rome against Italy’s referendum featured a photograph of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.
item.description: The prime minister has quit over the loss, but won’t be gone from the political arena long, one expert predicts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO, GAIA PIANIGIANI and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Kidlington Journal: British Villagers Are Baffled by Flocking Chinese Tourists
item.media:description: Chinese tourists taking pictures in Kidlington, England, last month. Ever since busloads of Chinese tourists began arriving this summer, residents of the sleepy Oxfordshire village have been variously baffled, annoyed and delighted.
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Dalziel for The New York Times
item.description: The rather ordinary village of Kidlington has become a popular stop for Chinese visitors who snap photographs of its simple homes, bushes and streets.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Pakistan’s Premier Honors Nobel Laureate From Persecuted Minority
item.description: Abdus Salam, a theoretical physicist, was honored by having a department of physics at one of the nation’s leading public universities renamed after him.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: Rohingya Face Health Care Bias in Parts of Asia, Study Finds
item.media:description: A sick Rohingya man waited in 2014 for a pharmacy to open at an camp near Sittwe in Rakhine State, Myanmar.
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.description: A report by Harvard researchers in The Lancet found that health care indicators were consistently worse for the Rohingya, a Muslim ethnic group.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Italy Just Handed the Global Economy Another Giant Variable
item.media:description: A branch of Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena in Rome. Bank stocks have fallen since Italian voters rejected changes that would have sped reforms to the country’s economy.
item.description: As the country’s voters emphatically rejected reforms in a referendum Sunday, they added to grave international uncertainties and prompted the prime minister to resign.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: Trump Call Gauged Positively, but Cautiously, in Taiwan
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan speaking with President-elect Donald J. Trump from her office in Taipei on Friday.
item.description: In Taipei, the capital, residents said they were pleased about the call between President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan and President-elect Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS HORTON

item.title: Japan Is Obsessed With Climate Change. Young People Don’t Get It.
item.media:description: Earth Parade 2015 in Tokyo, which was held to call attention to the fight against climate change.
item.description: Because the country has to import most of its energy, an apparent drop in concern by Japanese young people alarms many government officials.
item.dc:creator: TATIANA SCHLOSSBERG
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Bhutan Faces an Important Test of Press Freedom
item.description: A prominent journalist has been accused of libel for sharing a Facebook post that alleged corrupt dealings among the elite in the Asian country.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Bob Dylan Speech Will Be Read at the Nobel Prize Ceremonies
item.media:description: Bob Dylan at the White House in 2012, where he was presented with a Medal of Freedom.
item.description: The musician Patti Smith will perform a song by Mr. Dylan, who will not be attending the ceremony to receive his Nobel Prize for literature.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: Britain’s Supreme Court Hears Legal Challenge to ‘Brexit’
item.media:description: Supporters and opponents of Britain’s leaving the European Union clashed outside the Supreme Court in London on Monday.
item.description: The case’s outcome could affect the timetable laid down by the prime minister, who wants to start withdrawal negotiations by the end of March.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Trump’s Call with Taiwan: A Diplomatic Gaffe or a New Start?
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump at a rally in Cincinnati last week. Two of his Twitter assertions about China, on tariffs and the South China Sea, were broadly correct. A third, about China’s currency, was out of date.
item.description: Donald J. Trump has challenged Beijing on trade and the South China Sea, rejecting suggestions that he needed China’s approval to talk to Taiwan’s president.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: In a Year of Election Upsets, Uzbekistan Delivers the Expected
item.media:description: Voters in Tashkent, the capital of Uzbekistan, casting their ballots in the presidential election on Sunday.
item.description: After a campaign criticized for deep flaws, Shavkat Mirziyoyev, the prime minister, was chosen as the country’s second permanent president since independence.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: John Key, New Zealand’s Prime Minister, Says He Will Step Down
item.description: The 55-year-old prime minister, of the conservative National Party, has been in office since 2008, and his tenure has been seen as generally stable and free of controversy.
item.dc:creator: BRETT COLE

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Don’t Worry About the Italy Vote
item.media:description: Prime Minister Matteo Renzi speaking to the media in Rome, on Monday.
item.description: It was a rejection of the prime minister, not of the European Union.
item.dc:creator: BEPPE SEVERGNINI

item.title: Editorial: A Momentary Setback for Europe’s Right-Wingers
item.media:description: Alexander Van der Bellen celebrating in Vienna on Sunday.
item.description: Austrian voters reject an anti-immigrant candidate, but the populists are far from vanquished.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How the War Ends in Syria
item.media:description: Syrian government soldiers in Aleppo on Saturday.
item.description: It’s happening, so the U.S. should work with Russia for the least bad outcome.
item.dc:creator: PETER W. GALBRAITH
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
